title: I think by making ADC very overpowered you are making them the most stressful role of all
body:
In a Meta that determine which bottom lane is better, most of the time an ADC that lose their lane gets flamed very hard.
It's a stressful role as every single mistakes you make counts toward the failure of the game.
Can this get fixed? By making other roles like top and mid more impactful and Nerf Jungler Ganking and roaming to bottom lane?

If you have a 0/9 Darius and a 0/9 Xayah, most of the time people rather flame Ashe and call her you are the carry role.
Darius can lose early game but he can catch up because at least he is still useful, he brings utility and still do a decent amount of damage with no items.

I mean, adc's scale so hard they will always have the potential to be a high impact role in a game even when they aren't perceived as particularly strong in any given meta. This is just the nature of the way damage and ranged auto attacks work in this style of game. This is not unique to League. There are some moba's that can make melee hyper carries work, but League seems to have never successfully had a melee hyper carry that was deemed to have a healthy game play pattern (yasuo and fiora were notable attempts and we all know how that went).

This isn't entirely accurate, or at least not anymore. In Dota/Dota 2, carries are typically autoattack-based, but always included both melee and ranged heroes, and more recently also includes caster characters. Smite has damage-based carries of all ranges and types, many of which would be described as fighters in League. In HotS, most of the strongest/hardest-scaling characters in the game aren't autoattack-based at all, and many are melee. Even if the MOBA genre used to be fixated on autoattacks, it isn't anymore, and other games have shown many ways of evolving past that. In this respect, League's fixation on ranged autoattack-based damage dealers is unique to the game.

Dota has turn speed.
Smite aa's are skillshots.
HotS has teamwide level scaling and talents instead of items. 

Your examples certainly prove that mobas can make marksmen viable but not mandatory. However, they do not prove this is possible League, at least not without changing some fundamental principles.

I have tried to get into dota and hots and those two things in particular are not enjoyable to me. I've not tried smite, but having to turn the camera to look behind you is one of my least favorite things about FPSs (it is still possible to have skillshot aa's + top down camera, so this doesn't eliminate the mechanic, just smite's particular implementation).

Not saying it cannot be done, or even that it should not be done[1], just that hyper-scaling, mandatory-if-viable marksmen are baked into League's structure at a pretty fundamental level; it's not as trivial as "those games do it, so we can, too."

[1]: personally, I think crit spells would be a much healthier mechanic than crit aa's (tldr, because spells are more more varied), although I'm not sure if it would be possible to do that in League without making it a different game.

> [{quoted}](name=Hyrum Graff,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=8nhyv9pX,comment-id=000000000000,timestamp=2017-12-09T19:11:00.380+0000)
>
> Your examples certainly prove that mobas can make marksmen viable but not mandatory. However, they do not prove this is possible League, at least not without changing some fundamental principles.

Which is why I specified that League's marksman problem is unique to League. The point made by the person I was responding to was that ranged autoattackers had special status _across the entire MOBA genre_, which as I pointed out is demonstrably incorrect. I can happily talk about why I think marksmen in League are in the state they're currently in, and how that can change, but that's a different discussion.

> [{quoted}](name=Hyrum Graff,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=8nhyv9pX,comment-id=000000000000,timestamp=2017-12-09T19:11:00.380+0000)
> 
> Not saying it cannot be done, or even that it should not be done[1], just that hyper-scaling, mandatory-if-viable marksmen are baked into League's structure at a pretty fundamental level; it's not as trivial as "those games do it, so we can, too."

I don't personally think so, and in fact I think this mostly stems from habituation at marksmen being mandatory to League's team compositions, rather than any structural or other fundamental aspect of the game. Just this year we got a glimpse of a possible world where marksmen are no longer mandatory, with the appearance of Ziggs in bot lane, and the only reason that ended wasn't because the metagame naturally moved past it, but because marksmen were aggressively buffed to maintain hegemony there. It really isn't a case of marksmen being somehow necessary to League, as it is a case of them having received so much power over time, and having so many secondary systems built upon them (the near-totality of the Enchanter subclass, for example), that it _feels_ like they're necessary for the game to function.

> [{quoted}](name=Hyrum Graff,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=8nhyv9pX,comment-id=000000000000,timestamp=2017-12-09T19:11:00.380+0000)
> 
> [1]: personally, I think crit spells would be a much healthier mechanic than crit aa's (tldr, because spells are more more varied), although I'm not sure if it would be possible to do that in League without making it a different game.

I personally disagree completely: crit as a random mechanic feels more frustrating the wider the power differences it creates. It has remained somewhat acceptable on autoattacks, because autoattacks are individually meant to be weaker than spells in their damage application (this has changed over time, and I don't think crit is acceptable in any case, but this is the premise), and because they can be applied in rapid sequence, so pseudorandom AA crits tend to average out pretty quickly. Damaging spells, by contrast, are already meant to be individually strong as a baseline, and their variance comes from landing them or satisfying some other condition for their full application, so giving them the chance of dealing significantly more damage at random is likely to cause immense frustration and feelings of unfairness in a competitive game format. When Riot tested out a possible change this year which allowed Jinx's W to crit on the PBE, for example, they retracted it soon after, precisely for this reason. Again, the fact that this has happened shows that changes like these can happen without turning League into a different game, though not all of these changes are necessarily good for the game.

 I'm not sure in league to make adc optional, without making them absolutely unfun to play. Case in point: ziggs bot happened at the same time when people said "adc in 2k17" seriously.

This relates to the thing above because, at what point do you say, "you made marksmen fun and optional, but that game isn't league any more."? So yeah, other mobas can do it, but that doesn't mean league can.

Marksmen hyper-scale because crit gives them an extra level of multiplicative scaling. However, it doesn't have to be this way. For example, I'm pretty sure that hots marksmen don't have hyper-scaling damage. However, I think this change would be so disruptive to marksman players that, practically, will never happen. Maybe in a "league 2.0". This part is what ties together the three different things in this comment. 

> I personally disagree completely: crit as a random mechanic feels more frustrating the wider the power differences it creates. It has remained somewhat acceptable on autoattacks, because autoattacks are individually meant to be weaker than spells in their damage application (this has changed over time, and I don't think crit is acceptable in any case, but this is the premise), and because they can be applied in rapid sequence, so pseudorandom AA crits tend to average out pretty quickly. Damaging spells, by contrast, are already meant to be individually strong as a baseline, and their variance comes from landing them or satisfying some other condition for their full application, so giving them the chance of dealing significantly more damage at random is likely to cause immense frustration and feelings of unfairness in a competitive game format. When Riot tested out a possible change this year which allowed Jinx's W to crit on the PBE, for example, they retracted it soon after, precisely for this reason. Again, the fact that this has happened shows that changes like these can happen without turning League into a different game, though not all of these changes are necessarily good for the game.

That was the half sentence version, not full analysis. I'm not prepared to do the full thing now but here's a good short summary.

Ranged, targeted, infinite, highest dps, essentially 0 downtime => best in teamfights (because tanks), fastest objective takers, & good at seiging. Scales with gold more than levels => great duo laner. If you want optional adcs, something has to give.

By crit I meant another form of (hyper-)scaling, not the pRNG we have today. That might mean a % damage increase (like Ashe) or %arpen on crits or even utility scaling (also like Ashe, lol). This mostly can't work on adcs because of how reliable aa's are; riot has tried it internally and it makes adc vs adc matchups insanely snowbally. Spells already have more variance and longer cooldowns, so you have opportunities to win fights from behind, so they don't need rng tacked on to their scaling.

---

Before writing this, I thought it's impossible to make adcs optional because removing crit-level scaling from adcs is too disruptive. Now I'm thinking you might not have to, if you give spells crit scaling, too (plus put crit on ap items).

Their other quote, which you picked up on, was "There are some moba's that can make melee hyper carries work," implying that the ability for melee caries to function is something that has to be deliberately worked upon, rather than a feature innate to the MOBA genre.

Those are two separate statements. My direct response was that the status of marksmen in League is unique to League, not a problem endemic to the genre. My follow-up, however, is that the status of marksmen in League is also not one based on systems that cannot be changed -- because these systems can be improved, marksmen can become not mandatory, and even without these changes, we're not actually that far away from an environment where marksmen are non-essential, though still valuable.

"ADC in 2k17" was a notorious overreaction from people who felt their class was threatened. Marksmen were still largely essential, the problem just was that marksmen died more quickly if they got caught. The buffs that resulted made them even less fun to play _against_ for everyone else. If there is one takeaway to be had from that period, it is to not give too much damage to champions not meant to deal damage, in this case tanks (a problem that persists to this day).

> [{quoted}](name=Hyrum Graff,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=8nhyv9pX,comment-id=00000000000000000000,timestamp=2017-12-10T02:15:37.351+0000)

Again, games that featured Ziggs bot were still League, and they were still fun. In fact, many people praised the possibility of a non-marksman in the bot lane carry position, because it would've added immensely more diversity to the game. Similarly, while Mordekaiser bot was largely criticized due to how badly designed his kit was/is, many players were favorable to the idea of having _some_ non-marksman carry. League can have games where marksmen aren't essential because we've already had them, and so without even really deep changes. 

> [{quoted}](name=Hyrum Graff,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=8nhyv9pX,comment-id=00000000000000000000,timestamp=2017-12-10T02:15:37.351+0000)

Maybe in a "league 2.0". This part is what ties together the three different things in this comment. 

Except crit is a widely disliked stat that even Riot has criticized on several occasions. Again, I'm not suggesting removing crit is the way to go, but we already have several marksmen who do not really need crit to operate, and who play just fine. Marksman build diversity has never been better, and while some aspects of that may not be so great (marksmen depending on Lethality makes it harder to balance AD assassins), it just goes to show that crit is not this sacred, monolithic stat that absolutely needs to be preserved at all costs, for fear of "disrupting" marksmen.

> [{quoted}](name=Hyrum Graff,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=8nhyv9pX,comment-id=00000000000000000000,timestamp=2017-12-10T02:15:37.351+0000)
> 
> Ranged, targeted, infinite, highest dps, essentially 0 downtime => best in teamfights (because tanks), fastest objective takers, & good at seiging. Scales with gold more than levels => great duo laner. If you want optional adcs, something has to give.

I completely agree that something has to give. For one, I think fighters and marksmen should be on equal levels of DPS, particularly since fighters have to work more in general to be able to apply their own damage, but in addition to this I think marksmen are going to have to end up relying on their kits more in the future. For most champions, we've evolved past the era of ball-of-stats champions whose unique abilities only serve to amplify their items via on-demand steroids... except for marksmen. Champions like Twitch and Tristana are relics of that era, and more modern marksmen have unique enough abilities that they can be made more level-dependent. Marksmen like Caitlyn, Ezreal and Varus especially are already somewhat more level-dependent, as they were originally designed to be mid laners, and at this point the argument that marksmen _need_ to be more gold dependent no longer has any bearing, because marksman builds are the second-cheapest in the game, after support builds.

I would also add to the above that one of the reasons marksmen are currently mandatory is because they're the only damage class allowed to be late-game champions, with Riot [stating as much](https://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/gameplay-balance/bPE1A1gi-the-problem-with-adcs-is-they-do-too-much-damage-full-stop?comment=0005) during this year's Worlds (they also stated there that it was perfectly possible to switch primacy over from marksmen to other classes, such as battle mages). The notion of an entire class having the same power curve, aside from being impossible and harmful to in-class diversity, is also harmful to diversity across all champions, as here it means that carries from other classes are being deliberately relegated to second place at best, whereas marksmen who are naturally good early- or mid-game also get to enjoy an arbitrarily strong late game. Part of the issue with marksmen is effectively not so much that their damage output is somehow so special that it needs to be on every team (again, look at HotS and see which characters are the best teamfighters there), but that they're simply not made to run on the same design rules as every other class, to the detriment of everyone else.

But why? Are spells lacking in their ability to kill their intended targets right now? I don't think the answer to hyperscaling autoattacks should be to multiply the damage of ability-based nukes, as in their current state it would cause many single abilities to kill other champions in far too few hits, which would be immensely frustrating to all. Considering how there is frustration already at how marksmen are outputting burst-per-second, toning down their later autoattack damage would likely be a far better alternative.
